effect.then: I think this definition is broad enough to include robot life, purely digital life, non-terrain life, viruses. But it wouldn't include rocks, except in a much more rudimentary sense.

The definition could be treated quantitatively too, so that some things could be considered more alive than others. The more capable of diversifying patterns and remembering patterns, the more alive a thing is. Humans, then would be more alive than apes, and viruses.
Spend your life living, not just surviving. I mean Start now!
I am convinced that life is about discovery, creativity and love.

We already live, every day, through the means of outrageous actions with unforeseeable consequences to the whole world. The world population has doubled since 1970; the natural world, which used to surround humankind with its vast Gothic silences, is now something that has to be catalogued and cherished.
I am still wrestling with the meaning of life, but really like the subject.
Life is like, when physics creates something that can struggle to persist and reproduce.

I would define life as the kind of physical pattern sufficiently complex and otherwise capable of proliferating and diversifying its pattern set so as to persist and evolve. I think this definition is more general than most scientific definitions.
Life lies at the intersection of many forces, like some pagan power-spot at the junction of mysterious. And I'm cool with that.
